title: Pence and Pompeo’s Turkish mission impossible
text:
Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in Ankara, Turkey | Shaun Tandon/Pool/AFP via Getty Images Pence and Pompeo’s Turkish mission impossible Trump dispatches his top deputy and his top diplomat to convince Erdoğan to reverse his assault on northeastern Syria.

ANKARA, Turkey — From the outset, the mission had long odds.

President Donald Trump dispatched Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo here to the Turkish capital to try to convince Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan to reverse his assault on northeastern Syria — an assault Trump himself conceded was a long time coming.

But when they landed Thursday afternoon to the news that the Turkish premier tossed a letter from Trump in the trash, the task seemed to border on impossible.

Early Thursday afternoon, Pence and Pompeo walked out of the ambassador's residence here en route to the presidential palace to meet with Erdoğan wearing dark suits and stern looks. They posed for a photo, but declined to answer questions about their task at hand.

In reality, Pence and Pompeo’s mission is fraught with risk: The president sent his top deputy and his top diplomat to try to change the behavior of a foreign leader who has said in no uncertain terms that he has no intention of complying.

It was only the most recent setback for the United States as it tries to halt an invasion that has killed civilians, driven America’s former Kurdish allies into the arms of Syrian strongman Bashar al-Assad and caused the release of hundreds of ISIS prisoners.

Onboard Pompeo's plane — a modified Boeing 757 — there was a bit of turbulence, but no noticeable sign of the political storms raging on both sides of the Atlantic. TVs were tuned to Fox News upon takeoff. Dinner was chicken, potatoes and cheese, salad and a big slice of chocolate cake.

Pompeo’s trip will also take him to Jerusalem for consultations with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and to Brussels for a meeting with NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg.

It comes as the secretary grows more deeply enmeshed in the Democrats’ impeachment probe, with State Department staffers defying his orders to share their accounts of how the president’s personal lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, led a shadow foreign policy with Ukraine that cut out professional diplomats.

Just before departing Washington, a jacketless Pompeo dropped by the press cabin to say hello. He noted that the vice president is leading this delegation to Turkey, and said it was “our mission set to see if we can get a cease-fire” in Syria.

Back in Washington, a bipartisan duo of senators, Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) and Chris Van Hollen (D-Md.), are set to unveil a sanctions package punishing Turkey for its incursion, building on the more limited measures the administration announced earlier this week.

And the president’s top two military advisers, Defense Secretary Mark Esper and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Mark Milley, are holding a classified briefing on Capitol Hill to update lawmakers on developments in Syria.
description: Trump dispatches his top deputy and his top diplomat to convince Erdoğan to reverse his assault on northeastern Syria.
